text: Educational Studies in Japan: International Yearbook
label: BODY

text: No.4, December, 2009, pp.37-51
label: BODY

text: The Challenges of Fieldwork in Comparative Education Studies in
label: HH1

text: Japan: A Methodological Consideration
label: HH1

text: Otsuka, Yutaka*
label: BODY

text: The purpose of this article is not to discuss fieldwork at large but rather
label: BODY

text: to examine the position and role of the research method in one discipline, com-
label: BODY

text: parative education. For this purpose, first of all, the content of articles pub-
label: BODY

text: lished by the Japan Comparative Education Society’s journal over the past 35
label: BODY

text: years is analyzed. Based on this analysis, the implications, significance as well
label: BODY

text: as apprehension surrounding doing fieldwork in comparative studies of educa-
label: BODY

text: tion are then discussed. There are 504 articles published from the first volume
label: BODY

text: to the latest No. 39. The classification based on a full reading of all the articles
label: BODY

text: indicates 86 (approximately 17.1%) are found to be based on the data and
label: BODY

text: information collected and formed by the researchers themselves with the vari-
label: BODY

text: ous techniques in their fields. While studies about Western advanced countries
label: BODY

text: account for a majority in all articles, those utilizing various techniques in the
label: BODY

text: field remain limited at 20. The rest of the fieldwork-based articles concern
label: BODY

text: developing countries. However, an increasing number of fieldwork-based stud-
label: BODY

text: ies have been appearing in the JCES journal. Not only has the speed of this
label: BODY

text: increase been accelerating, but also the quality of the fieldwork seems to have
label: BODY

text: been improving gradually. Similarly, countries and areas to be the object of
label: BODY

text: investigation have been diversifying. What is perhaps the most salient phenom-
label: BODY

text: enon is that studies centering on advanced Western countries are also coming
label: BODY

text: to adopt fieldwork as their primary research method. These recent academic
label: BODY

text: trends may indicate that studies in Comparative Education in Japan are finally
label: BODY

text: coming into their own: what was long considered a ‘peripheral’ or ‘consumer’
label: BODY

text: position in academia is now being replaced with hope for making original and
label: BODY

text: active contributions to research in the field.
label: BODY

text: * Hiroshima University
label: BODY

text: e-mail: yotsuka@hiroshima-u.ac.jp
label: BODY

text: Fieldwork is defined loosely as an investigation technique for visiting sites in person with
label: BODY

text: a certain purpose in mind, making direct observations, interviewing parties concerned, conducting
label: BODY

text: questionnaire surveys, and extracting historical records and data on the spot in order to get scien-
label: BODY

text: tifically objective results. It has been described extensively over the years as a distinct research
label: BODY

text: method. Literature focusing on following sound interview techniques, the creation, distribution and
label: BODY

text: interpretation of questionnaires, the intricacies of reliable participant observation, the taking of
label: BODY

text: Otsuka,Yutaka
label: BODY

text: accurate field-notes and the writing of reports based on field experiences are too numerous to men-
label: BODY

text: tion.1 In the field of comparative education, which inherently involves the analysis of foreign coun-
label: BODY

text: try contexts or different cultural environments, fieldwork has been attracting more and more
label: BODY

text: attention as an effective and informative research method.
label: BODY

text: The purpose of this article is not to discuss the merits and processes of fieldwork at large,
label: BODY

text: but rather to confine the argument to examining the position and role of the method in one disci-
label: BODY

text: pline, comparative education. Since a vast majority of comparative educators in Japan maintain
label: BODY

text: membership in the Japan Comparative Education Society (JCES)2, the author will closely review
label: BODY

text: the Society’s past activities and clarify how fieldwork has been conducted and considered on vari-
label: BODY

text: ous occasions. More concretely, contents of the articles published by the Society’s journal over the
label: BODY

text: past 35 years will first be analyzed to ascertain their research methods. Secondly, based on this
label: BODY

text: analysis, the implications, significance, and apprehension surrounding doing fieldwork in compara-
label: BODY

text: tive studies of education are then discussed.
label: BODY

text: 1 Recognition of Fieldwork in the Initial Stage of JCES Development
label: HH2

text: The JCES started to publish its journal in 1974, the 10th year following its formal inaugu-
label: BODY

text: ration in 19653. The importance of fieldwork was recognized from the very beginning, as seen in
label: BODY

text: various articles in the first issue of the journal. For example, while advocating the ‘cultural anthro-
label: BODY

text: pology approach’, Tsuneo Ayabe listed the problems of conducting educational research using this
label: BODY

text: method in the past as follows: “Without carefully selecting research targets and building up and
label: BODY

text: scrutinizing precise hypotheses beforehand, research was actually conducted. .... It was not until
label: BODY

text: visiting the research site and incidentally coming across some educational issues that a survey was
label: BODY

text: started. .... Past studies lacked delving into the cognitive side of the context in the culture
label: BODY

text: concerned.”4
label: BODY

text: Subsequently, in proposals aimed at the improvement of research, Ayabe pointed out the
label: BODY

text: necessity of ‘educational ethnographic’ study based on in-depth participant observation over an
label: BODY

text: extended period of time. He also emphasized the importance of the ‘practical use of field survey
label: BODY

text: method’, referring not merely to the collection of ready-made materials at universities, government
label: BODY

text: offices, various kinds of schools, libraries, and research institutes located in urban cities of the
label: BODY

text: country concerned, but also in conducting first-hand research in rural areas where literature and
label: BODY

text: data are generally scarce. As for his interpretation of ‘practical use of a field research methods’,
label: BODY

text: he added that “it does not include the group tour and inspection tour staying in a hotel, or mere
label: BODY

text: study abroad, but is a means to carry out the investigation of an educational problem with concrete
label: BODY

text: awareness, by staying a long time in a selected spot, learning the local language, eating the local
label: BODY

text: food, and living the same life with local people.”5
label: BODY

text: In the article in the same edition entitled in “The Area Studies in the Field of Comparative
label: BODY

text: Education in Japan; The Example of Studying German Education,” Masaharu Amano suggested
label: BODY

text: that “comparative education studies in Japan probably need to advance more functional and effec-
label: BODY

text: tive research by introducing joint research systems and field surveys.”6 It is noteworthy that the
label: BODY

text: importance of fieldwork was pointed out from the standpoint of a researcher involved in the stud-
label: BODY

text: ies of advanced nations or Western countries.
label: BODY

text: In addition, Michiya Shimbori asserted that a mere study of education in a foreign country
label: BODY

text: could not be called “comparative education study, and education in two or more foreign countries
label: BODY

text: The Challenges of Fieldwork in Comparative Education Studies in Japan: A Methodological Consideration
label: BODY

text: should be compared methodologically and systematically”7, explaining that numerous approaches
label: BODY

text: are conceivable. However, it is not easy for Japanese researchers in particular to stay in a foreign
label: BODY

text: country long enough to master educational and various other aspects of the country, nor is travel
label: BODY

text: to foreign countries always easily accomplished. Moreover, even if researchers are able to secure
label: BODY

text: time and travel, average researchers still cannot easily grasp firsthand information due to restric-
label: BODY

text: tions of language or lifestyle habits. Therefore, Shimbori suggested that some alternative methods
label: BODY

text: for comparison depending on literature ought to be developed, claiming that “Only in this way we
label: BODY

text: can close the gap with Europe and American researchers who have few differences between a for-
label: BODY

text: eign country and their own country”8 [Italics not in the original]. From this assertion, it can be
label: BODY

text: surmised that Shimbori envisaged mainly the study of Western countries; other areas seem to have
label: BODY

text: been overlooked when forming his hypothesis, because it is not reasonable to state that Indonesia
label: BODY

text: and China, for example, are countries with “few differences” for European and American research-
label: BODY

text: ers. Rather, it should be considered that sensitive and cognitive distance toward these countries is
label: BODY

text: equally challenging for researchers, whether they are Japanese, European or American.
label: BODY

text: At any rate, judging from the above-mentioned arguments presented in the initial stages of
label: BODY

text: the development of the JCES, it can be observed that fieldwork methods were still in the early
label: BODY

text: stages in terms of how they could be effectively used. In fact, two individual research articles
label: BODY

text: appearing in the first edition of the journal as examples of actual research practice (i.e., “Arinori
label: BODY

text: Mori and Horace Mann” by Akie Shoko and “A Study of the International Aims of Education” by
label: BODY

text: Takashi Uehara) were both based on the results of the analysis of existing literature and published
label: BODY

text: data.
label: BODY

text: 2 Fieldwork Appearing as a Research Method
label: HH2

text: The issue of fieldwork was periodically taken up as a special topic in the JCES journal. In
label: BODY

text: the 1999 Special Edition of the journal (No.25) dealing with ‘New Perspectives of Comparative
label: BODY

text: Education’, we see a number of contributors referring to fieldwork as a research method. Minoru
label: BODY

text: Ishizuki wrote that “looking at recent research trends in Japan, it is remarkable that researchers of
label: BODY

text: the younger generation in particular are actively going abroad, energetically conducting field sur-
label: BODY

text: veys, and gathering information in the areas concerned.”9 He also pointed out “the areas of inves-
label: BODY

text: tigation are extending wider to include Africa, Central and South America and Oceania, which had
label: BODY

text: not received much attention in the past.”10 Shinichi Suzuki emphasized the necessity “to engage
label: BODY

text: directly by reflecting, developing and experimenting (i.e., conducting fieldwork) in relation to the
label: BODY

text: systematization of comparative education.”11 Akira Ninomiya expressed his pleasure that opportu-
label: BODY

text: nities for young researchers to conduct overseas research through the so-called “Tokubetsu Kenkyuin
label: BODY

text: Seido” or “special researcher program” of the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS),
label: BODY

text: have increased, and that significantly more researchers are able to have direct experience in devel-
label: BODY

text: oping countries as Japan Overseas Cooperation Volunteers of the Japan International Cooperation
label: BODY

text: Agency (JICA)12. Takeshi Sasamori discussed the relation between comparative education and area
label: BODY

text: studies from the viewpoint as a specialist of Oceania area studies. He indicated the importance of
label: BODY

text: “community surveys” and asserted that “the newest data and literature are difficult to acquire, espe-
label: BODY

text: cially with respect to countries in the South Pacific. Therefore, [fieldwork] is the best method for
label: BODY

text: collecting data and information.”13
label: BODY

text: In the same edition, Yokuo Murata and Megumi Shibuya discussed the relationship between
label: BODY

text: Otsuka,Yutaka
label: BODY

text: comparative education and area studies as specialists of Southeast Asia. They noted that in 10 vol-
label: BODY

text: umes (No. 15 to 24) of JCES journals, 18 articles had dealt with education in Southeast Asia,
label: BODY

text: including many studies in which contributors conducted original data collection and fieldwork
label: BODY

text: while staying for a relatively long period of time in the areas concerned. As for the research meth-
label: BODY

text: odology “most articles are based on a review of the literature using primary sources .... In addi-
label: BODY

text: tion, there are many studies in which researchers have utilized participant observation, interviews,
label: BODY

text: questionnaire surveys, scholastic ability tests, etc.”14 Specifically, the authors found that “among
label: BODY

text: these 18 articles, 6 studies utilized participant observation, 9 conducted interviews, and 4 did ques-
label: BODY

text: tionnaire surveys, which included either multiple choice or open-ended questions.”15
label: BODY

text: In the 2001 Special Editon of the journal (No. 27) entitled “The Frontier of Area Studies
label: BODY

text: in Education”, there is a review of studies concerning education in various contexts throughout the
label: BODY

text: world, and a discussion of future directions for research. The contributors to this Special Edition
label: BODY

text: were Hisao Takekuma (Southeast Asia), Hideaki Shibuya (South Asia), Yasuo Saito (Latin America),
label: BODY

text: Setsuo Nishino (Islamic countries in Southeast Asia), Tadashi Endo (Russia and the Soviet Union)
label: BODY

text: and Yutaka Kido (Europe). Each author is a specialist who has engaged in educational research in
label: BODY

text: their respective areas over many years as JCES members, and their intimate knowledge is reflected
label: BODY

text: in each article. Several articles in this Special Edition, for example, those by Takekuma, Shibuya,
label: BODY

text: Nishino and Endo, also refer to domestic and international trends in methods of fieldwork.
label: BODY

text: Table I classifies the content of JCES journal articles by country and other research themes,
label: BODY

text: illustrating how research foci and methodology within the JCES have evolved over time.
label: BODY

text: As indicated in Table I, looking back at all the articles published by the Journal, there were
label: BODY

text: 50416 published from the first volume to No. 39. If we narrow our focus to single countries (with
label: BODY

text: the exception of Japan) such as the United States and China, articles dealing with advanced coun-
label: BODY

text: tries in Europe and America received a majority of attention throughout the whole period. However,
label: BODY

text: if we consider change over each ten year period, it readily becomes apparent that articles dealing
label: BODY

text: with Asia, Oceania and other developing countries have been increasing. In addition, the number
label: BODY

text: of articles dealing with single countries seldom written about in the past has been increasing
label: BODY

text: rapidly.
label: BODY

text: As seen in Figure I, among 504 articles, 86 (approximately 17.1%) are found to be based
label: BODY

text: on original data and information collected and formed using various techniques in authors’ respec-
label: BODY

text: tive fields. This classification is based on a full reading of all 504 articles. These 86 articles are
label: BODY

text: distinguished by the criterion that the authors’ research techniques including questionnaires, inter-
label: BODY

text: views, and observations in their respective fields are explicitly indicated in any part of the article.
label: BODY

text: It appears that following edition No. 19 of the Journal, or since the beginning of the 1990s, research
label: BODY

text: utilizing fieldwork has come to be seen with increasing regularity in JCES publications. Therefore,
label: BODY

text: the period before this may be considered a ‘run-up stage.’ If we count the number of articles based
label: BODY

text: on fieldwork in all 10 volumes of the Journal, 10 appeared in Nos.1–10, 9 in Nos.11–20, 29 in
label: BODY

text: Nos. 21–30 and 38 in Nos.31–39. There is a particularly noticeable jump in the more recent 9 vol-
label: BODY

text: umes, which were published within the last 5 years.
label: BODY

text: An article referring to fieldwork investigation appeared for the first time in the Journal in
label: BODY

text: the 1976 volume (No.3). In “The Problems in Comprehensive Schools in Southeast Asia: A Thai
label: BODY

text: Case,” Shunichi Nishimura analyzed various problems involved in the movement toward the com-
label: BODY

text: prehensive school system which was a global thrust of education reform at that time. Nishimura
label: BODY

text: mentioned having conducted an analysis “based on my own experience of on-the-spot inquiries.”17
label: BODY

text: While the article does not emphasize the use of fieldwork methodology per se, it nevertheless rep-
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Otsuka,Yutaka
label: BODY

text: resents a significant contribution in being the earliest Society publication to report on findings
label: BODY

text: based on this approach. This is especially true if we consider the difficulty in traveling to a foreign
label: BODY

text: country to obtain detailed firsthand information in those days.
label: BODY

text: In addition, we can find five follow-up articles in this particular volume of the Journal that
label: BODY

text: followed the previous volume focusing on ‘Comparative Studies of Educational Research Systems
label: BODY

text: in Various Countries.’ This study was being systematically conducted as a common research proj-
label: BODY

text: ect by JCES members at that time. Although these articles are written based mostly on information
label: BODY

text: quoted from official documents, books and research articles published in the countries concerned,
label: BODY

text: there is an explanation in Taneo Harada’s article, “General View” that “for obtaining scarce (infor-
label: BODY

text: mation) or verifying questionable facts, ... a very practical method is to delegate investigative
label: BODY

text: responsibilities to those Society members currently visiting or living in the country in question,
label: BODY

text: and to supplement and collect the information they provide.”18
label: BODY

text: Among the previously mentioned 86 articles published by the Journal for which the authors
label: BODY

text: collected data through fieldwork (see Table II), only 20 (23.3%) were on Western advanced coun-
label: BODY

text: tries, whereas the overwhelming majority, 65 articles (75.6%) were concerned with non-Western
label: BODY

text: areas, especially those located in Asia.19 In addition to these, although not clearly mentioned in the
label: BODY

text: articles themselves, Masahiro Tejima’s “The Introduction of Islamic Values into Environmental
label: BODY

text: Education in Malaysia” 20 and Hirotaka Nanbu’s “The Process of Preparing Higher Education
label: BODY

text: Faculty in China” 21 implicitly included the contents of interviews with persons concerned in those

text: The Challenges of Fieldwork in Comparative Education Studies in Japan: A Methodological Consideration
label: BODY

text: countries. Koro Suzuki’s “Islamic Education in Public Primary and Secondary Schools in Southern
label: BODY

text: Thailand” 22 was also based on reports of local education administration offices in Southern Thailand,
label: BODY

text: which are not easily accessible in Japan, and seem to have been collected on the spot. However,
label: BODY

text: these articles were not counted as having been the result of fieldwork-based research.
label: BODY

text: While studies of advanced countries in the West account for a majority of all articles pub-
label: BODY

text: lished by the Journal as mentioned in Table I, those utilizing various fieldwork techniques remain
label: BODY

text: limited at 20. How might this fact be interpreted? For researchers who are involved in the study
label: BODY

text: of the Western world, is it sufficient merely to rely on a wealth of existing data in order to form
label: BODY

text: and meaningfully test a hypothesis? Unfortunately, in my opinion, there seems to be an overwhelm-
label: BODY

text: ing reliance on existing research results produced in advanced Western countries, based perhaps
label: BODY

text: on a ‘servile spirit’ (subordinate consciousness) of sorts on the part of Japanese researchers in terms
label: BODY

text: of research. In the light of this possibility, above-mentioned Masaharu Amano’s assertion seems to
label: BODY

text: exhibit more luster.
label: BODY

text: 3 Re-examining “Fieldwork”
label: HH2

text: Although there appear to be relatively more articles reporting findings based on ‘fieldwork’
label: BODY

text: undertaken in Asian countries, whether researchers’ practices in the field are in fact worthy of the
label: BODY

text: term should also be strictly examined from the following viewpoints.
label: BODY

text: First of all, fieldwork becomes self-contained only after appropriate activity is made in each
label: BODY

text: phase of the process, i.e.: (1) before going into the field, (2) in the field, and (3) after returning
label: BODY

text: from the field. Although the amount of data and information and the ease of access to these have
label: BODY

text: increased enormously in the present global and Internet age, are we able to fully digest the data
label: BODY

text: and information which are available before going to the actual site? In recent years, while some
label: BODY

text: vital details remain difficult to obtain, much information may be obtained instantly by connecting
label: BODY

text: to the World Wide Web from any access point around the globe.23
label: BODY

text: Second, the methodological processes that distinguish ‘fieldwork’ from other approaches
label: BODY

text: must be revisited. As indicated in Table III, in earlier days an overwhelming majority of the field-
label: BODY

text: work by Society members was based on questionnaire surveys, with only a few studies using addi-
label: BODY

text: tional interviews and observations. The situation gradually changed as studies based on interviews
label: BODY

text: increased. When we examine the methods utilized by the 86 fieldwork-based studies, interviews,
label: BODY

text: questionnaires and observations account for 49, 29 and 11 projects respectively, although some
label: BODY

text: researchers combined these methods and therefore the total exceeds 86 studies.
label: BODY

text: Regardless of the methods used, how can we ensure representativeness and typicality of
label: BODY

text: place, institution or respondent? Local research areas in which means of transportation are difficult
label: BODY

text: to secure require an abundance of energy and self-initiative. Nevertheless, the research rationale
label: BODY

text: must be assessed rigorously; even if a study is worthy of a prize for effort, it may not be very use-
label: BODY

text: ful in terms of building new theories, providing new knowledge, or contributing otherwise to the
label: BODY

text: field of comparative education.
label: BODY

text: Moreover, in a humanistic educational science which has as its core purpose the understand-
label: BODY

text: ing of human being, face-to-face communication, direct dialog and personal contextual experience
label: BODY

text: are undeniably the most effective research methods. While questionnaire surveys are practical alter-
label: BODY

text: natives to meeting with respondents personally, comparative educationalists are obliged to strive
label: BODY

text: to discern the ‘heart of the matter’ through personal engagement and involvement. It is the field
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: The Challenges of Fieldwork in Comparative Education Studies in Japan: A Methodological Consideration
label: BODY

text: that requires observation in order to obtain results which cannot be gained through considerations
label: BODY

text: of literature alone. The field creates an image which can neither be trivialized nor exaggerated.
label: BODY

text: Ethnographic investigation centering on long-term participant observation in the field is often con-
label: BODY

text: sidered antithetical to questionnaire survey. Of course, the former is only one survey method, as
label: BODY

text: are intensive interviews, scholastic aptitude and psychological tests, the collection and scrutiny of
label: BODY

text: literature as well as statistical data and other materials. The importance of ‘watching and listening’
label: BODY

text: cannot be denied, however the danger of having no choice but to devote one’s time to ‘watching
label: BODY

text: and listening’ should not be forgotten. Ethnographic investigation is a proven method of recording
label: BODY

text: observations of educational activity, which are very individualized.
label: BODY

text: In this respect, studies based on ‘participant observation’ that have been conducted by mem-
label: BODY

text: bers of the Society should be open for discussion about whether researchers have indeed followed
label: BODY

text: appropriate methodological rigors to justify this claim. After having analyzed the studies by our
label: BODY

text: Society members, what can be said at present is that we will likely have to wait until more qual-
label: BODY

text: ity monographs and articles have been accumulated in order for this method to take root in our
label: BODY

text: field. A distinctive methodology of fieldwork cannot be established until such individual studies
label: BODY

text: accumulate and achievements which cannot be reduced to any existing discipline are established.
label: BODY

text: It is not always the case that the length of stay in any given fieldwork context translates as
label: BODY

text: ‘the longer the better.’ It is likely that short-term results from a novice researcher who is unfamil-
label: BODY

text: iar with the area concerned may not be as valuable as those of a specialist who has been commit-
label: BODY

text: ted to researching and living in an area for a long period of time. Three outstanding studies24
label: BODY

text: conducted by Society members are particularly noteworthy, in that they reflect dedication to the
label: BODY

text: field and involve participant observation as a main research technique. These studies demonstrate
label: BODY

text: an attempt to grasp the changes in a village or educational institution not with a shortsighted or
label: BODY

text: hasty attitude but from a long-term perspective.
label: BODY

text: There has been much concern in recent years that our increasingly global, achievement-
label: BODY

text: oriented academic climate results in pressure to complete studies more quickly. In such circum-
label: BODY

text: stances, an environment is being established in which long and enduring field surveys with close
label: BODY

text: linkages to investigation target sites, as expressed by the phrase ‘one person in one village for one
label: BODY

text: year’ in cultural anthropology, will be difficult to realize in our discipline in coming years. Hopefully
label: BODY

text: this concern will prove unfounded.
label: BODY

text: Third, regardless of whether a study is conducted on an individual or collaborative basis,
label: BODY

text: human relations involved must be reexamined. Fieldwork performed by an individual researcher
label: BODY

text: should be strongly encouraged when there appears to be a certain field or theme of study that an
label: BODY

text: individual can pursue. Of course, a major premise of individual fieldwork is that what an individ-
label: BODY

text: ual can and should do must be performed alone. In this respect, it is sometimes seen that an indi-
label: BODY

text: vidual who is involved in a country’s development in a professional capacity (hereafter referred as
label: BODY

text: ‘development practitioner’) mobilizes local consultants and specialists to collect related data and
label: BODY

text: information and utilizes results in creating a report. In order to quickly grasp the complicated social
label: BODY

text: relations in an area and accurately reflect results in a publicized project, various know-how and
label: BODY

text: techniques using mainly qualitative methods to complete an investigation in a short period of time
label: BODY

text: must be worked out thoroughly in advance. However, ‘problem-finding type’ investigations often
label: BODY

text: adopted by researchers deeply involved in a local area generally do not easily fit within the time-
label: BODY

text: frame of development practitioners. Are not comparative education researchers engaged in a task
label: BODY

text: similar to that of the practitioners? To rephrase this question, does the successful collection of data
label: BODY

text: negate any need to question the process? Indeed, it would also appear necessary to consider the
label: BODY

text: Otsuka,Yutaka
label: BODY

text: internal changes and mental development of the researcher.
label: BODY

text: There are many circumstances in fieldwork whereby two or more researchers, including the
label: BODY

text: researcher of the area concerned, are necessarily involved. It is certain that an investigation con-
label: BODY

text: ducted by one person has an advantage in terms of simplicity and rapport with those surveyed with
label: BODY

text: the provision that it is carried out well. While it is often said that ‘two heads are better than one,’
label: BODY

text: conducting fieldwork investigation on an individual basis can have considerable advantages over
label: BODY

text: collective efforts. However, in terms of reliability and verifiability of survey results and falsifiabil-
label: BODY

text: ity in reverse, a group investigation is more effective than an individual investigation.
label: BODY

text: To examine more concretely the relation between individual and group investigation, we
label: BODY

text: can consider the use of language. With respect to survey language, it is a minimum requirement
label: BODY

text: for a person entering into the field to have a thorough knowledge of the language used in that field.
label: BODY

text: It is inexcusable for a professional researcher who emphasizes fieldwork to intend to complete an
label: BODY

text: investigation only in Japanese or English in an area where a third language is used in common
label: BODY

text: discourse. However, to acquire sufficient proficiency in a foreign language to enable one to con-
label: BODY

text: duct research in that language involves no small amount of time, energy and dedication. Moreover,
label: BODY

text: it is very difficult, though not necessarily impossible, to take up a theme that is related to multi-
label: BODY

text: language issues in an area consisting of multiple races and many languages, and to navigate lan-
label: BODY

text: guages other than the national language or a dominant language. It is not rare that multiple linguistic
label: BODY

text: interpretations intervene between the researcher and those surveyed. Investigation may furthermore
label: BODY

text: be carried out in collaboration with a researcher of the area concerned who is not simply a linguis-
label: BODY

text: tic translator. In such a case, it becomes key to the success or failure of a whole investigation
label: BODY

text: whether long-lasting relationships can be built between researchers in the field concerned. Such
label: BODY

text: researchers, would hold the consciousness of being ‘partners’ in the literal sense, rather than uti-
label: BODY

text: lizing local ‘auxiliary persons’ in capacities such as translator.
label: BODY

text: Generally speaking, there are a host of potential sources of complications hindering suc-
label: BODY

text: cessful engagement in fieldwork. With respect to cooperation with the local persons concerned, as
label: BODY

text: a foreigner a Japanese comparative education researcher cannot always enjoy free choice in the
label: BODY

text: selection of fieldwork locations and institutions in every country. There often exist barriers for
label: BODY

text: which individual researchers can do nothing about, as experienced particularly in socialist coun-
label: BODY

text: tries.25 Another frequent problem involves perceptions of success: If a researcher gains the impres-
label: BODY

text: sion that his or her fieldwork in a foreign country has progressed smoothly, it is tempting to believe
label: BODY

text: that the preliminary target level may have been too low, or that some unforeseeable force was at
label: BODY

text: work behind the scenes. What we can do is to use our brains to get the most out of given condi-
label: BODY

text: tions. Collaboration between Japanese comparative education researchers and those in the field
label: BODY

text: concerned is indispensable from this viewpoint. It can be stated with conviction that first of all,
label: BODY

text: good human relationships built up over a long period of time determine the success or failure of
label: BODY

text: much fieldwork.
label: BODY

text: 4 The Field as ‘Method’
label: HH2

text: For the purpose of promoting active research in comparative education by Japanese schol-
label: BODY

text: ars, Toru Umakoshi pointed out that more ‘area studies’ should first of all be conducted. He also
label: BODY

text: proposed a concrete path (a reciprocating movement of ‘area studies’ and ‘theorization’) towards
label: BODY

text: correcting existing theories rooted in each discipline.26 When we confront various educational phe-
label: BODY

text: The Challenges of Fieldwork in Comparative Education Studies in Japan: A Methodological Consideration
label: BODY

text: nomena seen in each field by using existing disciplines and theories, we must recognize that most
label: BODY

text: of these disciplines and theories have been created in the West. Edward Said’s assertion that
label: BODY

text: “Orientalism [is] a Western style for dominating, restructuring, and having authority over the
label: BODY

text: Orient”27 is in fact a reflection of Western ethnocentrism. His view is nevertheless extremely impor-
label: BODY

text: tant for studies which consider non-Western areas as the field within comparative education research.
label: BODY

text: Furthermore, Japanese scholars receive the benefit of using existing disciplines and theories as
label: BODY

text: research tools in the process of academic training, regardless of whether we have internalized or
label: BODY

text: merely superficially accepted them. Therefore, the suggestion by Yasushi Maehira that ‘reverse eth-
label: BODY

text: nocentrism’28 medially-located among Japanese scholars should be regarded is an important
label: BODY

text: concept.
label: BODY

text: There has been numerous debate over the years as to whether or not area studies can be
label: BODY

text: considered an independent discipline by itself. It is not my wish here to side definitely in favor of
label: BODY

text: one view or the other. However whether we should place more emphasis on the ‘field’ or on ‘exist-
label: BODY

text: ing theories’ does seem to present a profound issue. What any approach must reflect is the under-
label: BODY

text: standing of the field not as a place for ‘sample’ extraction in order to verify or refute existing
label: BODY

text: theories. This trivialized way of thinking will not lead to the development of an original theory
label: BODY

text: peculiar to the field that begins with some holistic perception. This author believes that it is time
label: BODY

text: to discard any attachment to the weak eclecticism of all-encompassing approaches, to dare to turn
label: BODY

text: down the ambiguity of exploring the modifiability of the existing theories, just to thoroughly per-
label: BODY

text: ceive what the field suggests without interposing any preconception. This viewpoint is also related
label: BODY

text: to differences in whether the same ‘study on Thai education’, for example, can be viewed as a
label: BODY

text: branch of ‘Thai study’, or as a branch of ‘education study’. The “field” itself expresses totality,
label: BODY

text: and it involves something completely different from segmentalized themes such as ‘basic educa-
label: BODY

text: tion curriculum of country A,’ and ‘decentralization of the educational administration of country
label: BODY

text: B’. Therefore, let us suppose that a specified theme is apparently dealt with in several studies; the
label: BODY

text: boundary line which speaks to the genuine value of those studies is whether the theme is selected
label: BODY

text: independently by chance, or is based on full consideration and discernment backed by overall deep
label: BODY

text: understanding of the field accumulated over a long period of time.
label: BODY

text: Regarding the unit of analysis or investigation target, as shown in Table III, a variety of
label: BODY

text: units are analyzed in field-based studies, from cross-national perspectives of eight countries, to one
label: BODY

text: specific classroom and even to an individual scholar29. There seems to be a general tendency in
label: BODY

text: fieldwork where researchers focus on small unit such as a village or a school. In any case, in com-
label: BODY

text: parison with researchers who do not enter the field, those who do are distanced from their own
label: BODY

text: culture, and much more frequently encounter situations where they cannot avoid reviewing their
label: BODY

text: own cultures more objectively. Criticism that there is “no comparison”30 in research results by
label: BODY

text: JCES members often proves justified and must be accepted with sincerity. Nevertheless, the
label: BODY

text: researcher who is deeply committed to the field is always personally engaged in ‘comparison,’ and
label: BODY

text: is continuously pressed to make value judgments from a comparative viewpoint in the process of
label: BODY

text: investigation and reporting.
label: BODY

text: This is the meaning of ‘the field as method,’ which helps to contribute to character-
label: BODY

text: building on the part of the researcher. In such daily, repeated ‘comparison,’ it is ideal for Japanese
label: BODY

text: researchers not only to put a pivoting foot of comparison on our own cultural setting, but hope-
label: BODY

text: fully to seek out more perspectives and consider things from different angles. It is not sufficient
label: BODY

text: only to consider various phenomena occurring in the field with the inborn views and ways of think-
label: BODY

text: ing as Japanese. Junzo Kawada called this concept ‘triangulation’31; Kazuko Tsurumi showed the
label: BODY

text: Otsuka,Yutaka
label: BODY

text: same recognition in her works on Pearl Buck and John Dewey.32 It is possible to consider more
label: BODY

text: objectively and essentially the phenomenon seen in the field not by a simple comparison between
label: BODY

text: two things, but by adding more perspectives and analyzing within a somewhat more complicated
label: BODY

text: framework. On this point, Chie Nakane once pointed out the importance of having interest and
label: BODY

text: practical knowledge in more than two research areas, such as ‘major’ and ‘minor’ fields. She stated
label: BODY

text: that those geographical areas should be somewhere other than within the society in which the
label: BODY

text: researcher was born and raised, reasoning that “if we choose the area in which we were born and
label: BODY

text: raised, our observation will be inevitably less rigorous in method.”33 In general, in acquiring knowl-
label: BODY

text: edge of a certain field, if we cling only to the field, we may not be able to have a very broad and
label: BODY

text: deep understanding of it. However, unfortunately we can find few works in the JCES Journal that
label: BODY

text: were written from a triangulated or multifaceted standpoint.
label: BODY

text: Thus, although the field may be is likened to ‘a treasure mountain’, neither is the mountain
label: BODY

text: easily climbed nor can the treasures be found merely lying around. Even if physical and objective
label: BODY

text: conditions are all provided for, not everyone is necessarily able to capitalize upon them. Only those
label: BODY

text: standing in the field who have “a direct sensitivity to the material before them, and then a contin-
label: BODY

text: ual self-examination of their methodology and practice, a constant attempt to keep their work
label: BODY

text: responsive to the material and not to a doctrinal preconception”,34 are successful in finding their
label: BODY

text: treasures. Ultimately, the ideal fieldwork technique can be created only by researchers who con-
label: BODY

text: tinuously refine themselves in the field. In this way, an original theory, not to mention a new dis-
label: BODY

text: cipline, will be produced through persistent and close dialog with data and information35 obtained
label: BODY

text: and accumulated in the field; ‘an original theory’ in this case includes not only drawing conclu-
label: BODY

text: sions from case studies, but also typifying the results obtained from two or more case studies and
label: BODY

text: further interrelating them on a more advanced, abstract level. Some kind of ‘synthesis’ process is
label: BODY

text: required, and eventually an achievement that is non-reducible to any existing discipline should be
label: BODY

text: the end result. There is little value in studies on a foreign country or comparative studies which
label: BODY

text: merely reuse and rearrange original research results.
label: BODY

text: Another point to be considered regarding fieldwork, as indicated in the title of the present
label: BODY

text: paper, is the field as an educational material or learning resource; i.e., a survey in certain field
label: BODY

text: adopted as part of course work for students majoring in comparative education. In some Japanese
label: BODY

text: universities36 the requirement of overseas fieldwork has been already adopted as part of the curric-
label: BODY

text: ulum. The crucial problem of such overseas fieldwork, as I have discussed in detail elsewhere37,
label: BODY

text: include the scarcity of student involvement in the planning stages and the possibility that research
label: BODY

text: will devolve into a ‘quasi-survey’. As already stated, when the composition of fieldwork is con-
label: BODY

text: sidered, the success or failure of the whole study depends on precedent survey design or selection
label: BODY

text: of sites, institutions, informants or interviewees. Therefore, survey design should be completed
label: BODY

text: prior to actually doing observation and data collection in the field, which forms the middle phase
label: BODY

text: of the survey (the final stage being reporting). In overseas fieldwork for the training of students,
label: BODY

text: the extent to which students take part in this important process is, regretfully, extremely limited or
label: BODY

text: almost nil.
label: BODY

text: 5 Conclusion
label: HH2

text: More and more fieldwork-based studies have been appearing in the JCES journal with each
label: BODY

text: new edition. The initial 10 volumes since its inauguration contain 10 articles based on fieldwork
label: BODY

text: The Challenges of Fieldwork in Comparative Education Studies in Japan: A Methodological Consideration
label: BODY

text: and the next 10 volumes contain 9 articles. In the third decade, 29 articles based on fieldwork
label: BODY

text: appeared, and 38 articles within the latest 5 years (owing largely to the decision in 2006 to pub-
label: BODY

text: lish two editions per year). Not only has the rate of increase been accelerated, but also the quality
label: BODY

text: of the fieldwork seems to have been improving gradually. Countries and areas to be the object of
label: BODY

text: investigation have been diversifying. Focusing on the most recent 9 volumes (Nos. 31–39), only 3
label: BODY

text: out of 38 articles depend solely on questionnaire survey which had been the typical technique used
label: BODY

text: in fieldwork in previous years. Five articles utilize observation, although the length of time in the
label: BODY

text: field varies from article to article. The remaining 31articles utilize the interview method, of which
label: BODY

text: 6 articles are based on composite methods of interview and questionnaire or observation. A partic-
label: BODY

text: ularly noteworthy phenomenon is that studies centering on Western advanced countries are also
label: BODY

text: adopting fieldwork as their research method. The younger generations involved with those coun-
label: BODY

text: tries are trying to positively form their own data and information, as was the case for studies on
label: BODY

text: developing countries, instead of ‘borrowing’ or ‘consuming’ ready-made research results. These
label: BODY

text: recent academic trends may indicate that studies in comparative education in Japan are finally com-
label: BODY

text: ing into their own: what was long considered a ‘peripheral’ or ‘consumer’ position in academia is
label: BODY

text: now being replaced with true hope for making original and active contributions to research in the
label: BODY

text: field.38
label: BODY

text: Acknowledgement
label: HH2

text: I am greatly indebted to Dr. Arthur Meerman, Associate Professor of Kurume University
label: BODY

text: for all his helpful comments. However, all shortcomings and errors are my own.
label: BODY

text: Notes
label: HH3

label: BODY

text: Natural Sociology, Englewood Cliffs, N.J.: Prentice-Hall, 1973. Roger Sanjek ed., Fieldnotes: A Making of
label: BODY

text: Anthropology, Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornel University Press, 1990. Ikuya Sato, Fieldwork, Tokyo: Shinyosha, 1992. Robert
label: BODY

text: 2  1,003 members belong to JCES as of June 2009 and it is one of the largest educational societies except for the
label: BODY

text: Japanese Educational Research Association, the comprehensive learned society of education in this country.
label: BODY

text: 3  The Society organized four preparatory annual conferences prior to its formal inauguration in 1965. Since this time,
label: BODY

text: the name and style of the Society’s journal has changed a few times; i.e., Hikaku Kyoiku Gakkai Kiyo (Bulletin of
label: BODY

text: the Japan Comparative Education Society) of the inaugural issue in 1975, Hikaku Kyoikugaku (Comparative Education)
label: BODY

text: of No. 14 in 1988, and Hikaku Kyoikugaku Kenkyu (Studies in Comparative Education) in 1990. It was published
label: BODY

text: once a year from its inauguration until the 2005 issue, following which the Society decided to publish the journal
label: BODY

text: twice a year from No. 32 in 2006. Thirty nine issues have been published as of 2009. In this article, Bulletin of JCES
label: BODY

text: is used in the references as representing these three different names.
label: BODY

text: 23  Considering the case of China, the present author’s research area, the situation existed until approximately 15 years
label: BODY

text: ago whereby sources of obtainable information were limited to general newspapers and magazines such as the People’s
label: BODY

text: Daily, Guangming Daily, the Red Flag, as well as a limited number of education-related books and magazines.
label: BODY

text: Nowadays, although the objectivity and validity of reporting may remain questionable, voluminous books and maga-
label: BODY

text: zines exclusively on educational-related topics are being published in China. No longer are visits to the Ministry of
label: BODY

text: Education in Beijing necessary to obtain the most basic data such as school or enrolled student numbers.
label: BODY

text: 24  In fact, there are studies which deserve close attention among those utilizing ethnographic methods by our members.
label: BODY

text: Mina Hattori’s article based on participant observation and interviews during her two-and-a-half year stay in Diniyyah
label: BODY

text: Puteri, a women’s Islamic school in Padang Panjang of West Sumatra, was bestowed the Hiratsuka Award which was
label: BODY

text: established in 1990 to commemorate the first president of JCES, Dr. Masunori Hiratsuka, as well as to encourage and
label: BODY

text: reward young scholars’ research achievement. Takashi Nozu has entered Yasothon County in northeastern Thailand
label: BODY

text: intermittently since 1996 and continues to observe school culture. Another example is the study by Shigeo Nishimura,
label: BODY

text: which compared and contrasted the changes in education in Nappon, a small village in north Sumatra, from the early
label: BODY

text: 1970s to the present.
label: BODY

text: 25  Taking China as an example, even if the desired site of fieldwork has been decided upon, it is impossible to unilater-
label: BODY

text: ally specify the area below the county (xian) level according to investigation design.
